text: Keg @ Cafe Beermoth, Manchester. Pours a misty pale gold, small white head. Aroma of wit spice, yeast, lightly sour. Soft wit taste, lightly spicy, peppery, not a bad effort.

750 cc, capped, from Frank Smiths. Pours clear golden with 2-fingers of fluffy, white head and a high level of carbonation. Nose is wheaty pale malt, hops, kiwi. Tastes smooth, complex, with pale malt, hops, kiwi, wheat, florals, mild white peppery spice. This is an incredible witbier, and certainly must be in my top 10 for this style, if not higher.
Draft taster at Churchkey. Pale yellow with bare head. A: tons of flora, some yeast, garden spice, coriander. T: subdued version of aroma, some lite green tea. OK.
4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey. Slightly hazy yellow with off-white head. Aromas of herb, spice, lemon citrus. Tastes of herb, spice, wheat, light malt. Light body with a dry finish.
Draft at The Sovereign. Clear yellow color. Spice forward aroma. Taste is spiced straw. OK.

Draft. Medium white head atop hazy light amber body, Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, some coriander, white pepper, light honey, funk, lemon. Taste is medium sweet, berry, some orange, light pepper. Light-medium body, low carbonation.
Hazy golden color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, floral/fruit, some clove, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, coriander, fruit, and spice; Dry finish; Nicely balanced; Good.

Bottle, no 4324. Pours clear, light yellow, with a big creamy head setting at finger thickness. Aroma is tart with yeast, hay and soapy notes, as well as some malts with bread. Medium body, with average to fizzy carbonation. Flavour is tart yeast, hay and light farmhouse notes, as well as wood and sweet notes of honey and soap.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with white head. Spicy, wheat, yeast, bread aromas. Spicy, yeast, wheat, peppery, slight citrus flavors. Just an awesome all-around belgian white

Rating #1737 - 2015.06.08 - Bottle from @yegbeergirl- Pours a hazy yellow with a bubbly white head. Aroma is passionfruit, citrus and grapefruit. Decent bitterness, a hint of spice that lingers in finish. Lovely.
Bottle. Cloudy wheat color . Very flavorful floral fruity taste. Very easy drinking and European. I'd have it again

Bottle @ home
Coriander, wheat, orange blossom
Very carbonated, refreshing, wheat, coriander, bread, light hoppy ending

drank only because of the label, i love giraffes .. . cloudy hazed amber .. great foam .. oats, wheat, coriander, sausage skin, husks, mild fruit, and toto .. . mouth feels nice, refreshing and a bit light. a great wit .. . . I was once kissed on the lips by a giraffe, and I dont think Ive ever got over it.

750 from hayduke and we had it together via facebook chat. Almost clear golden and carbonation is visible as it rises. The white foam gushed from the bottle. I smell coriander and wheat with some lemon. All of that is tasted, too. The coriander also seems to come with berries. There is some sourness to this. Some fruit and yeast and then melons. The finish was funky and earthy.

Shared with Strykzone on Facebook Chat. From the 750 ml bottle, it poured a very cloudy almost butterscotch yellow. Lots of carbonation raised a big white head and good lacing. Light to medium body and again a lot of carbonation. The flavor is complex. Starts with a lot of sourness and a big burst of coriander. Them both lemon and peach arrive. As we move into the earthy finish there is a lot of spice and the funk stays all the way to the end, This was one to be sipped not chugged. Good beer and enjoyable from start to finish. Glad the ABV is reasonable as this was a lot of beer.

750ml bottle. Hazy, yellow-ish, pale golden colour with average to huge, fluffy, more than fairly lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Wheaty, fruity, and yeasty spicy aroma, notes of peach, apricot, mirabelle (partially in dried state), white pepper, shallot. Taste is dry hoppy, fruity, notes of (dried) apricot, nectarine, peach, underlying (wheaty) sweetness, mild peppery spiciness, a herbal-grassy touch, tart-ish lemon interludes. Well balanced, pronounced flavours, marvellous.

On tap at Nedre Foss Gård, may 13th 2015. Hazy yellow body, nice white head. Citrussy aroma with lime, brett funk, wheat, choriander. Taste is lightly sweet, zesty fruity, peppery and dry. Clean fresh yeast notes with orange and straw in finish. Yet another very nice beer from Logsdon.

0.375l bottle. Very hazy golden body, huge white head. Aroma of bread, lemon zest and quite a lot of coriander. Taste of bread, yeast, lemon zest and coriander. Sweet upfront but the finish is a bit sour (like lemon juice). Nice beer.

375 mL bottle purchased at the Logsdon barrel house. Ive seen this bottle around for years, and always loved the label art as a bonus, but always passed due to price. Turns out Logsdon beers are much less expensive at the source. Good to know since I know for a fact that I will be back. Cloudy apple juice color pour with a quick fading head. Soft orange and spice aroma. Flavor has many qualities of a usual wit, but the spice profile, and carb to it make it a stand out for me. Coupled with the long wait of trying this beer, I very much enjoyed it.

Bottle. Pale gold in colour with slight haze and fairly strong carbonation. Aromas are of honeycomb, lime pith, and coriander. Flavors are reminiscent of lemon lime soda, flaked wheat, mild white pepper, and more coriander. On the lean side of a wit, but very refreshing and refined.
750ml bottle pours out a cloudy golden topped with a white head. nose is banana cardamom plenty of spice and a wheat. Taste is more of the spice banana bread cardamom.
(750ml bottle) Pours a hazy pale yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of wheat, coriander, banana, and citrus. Flavor of yeast, coriander, minerals, and citrus peel with a dry finish.

Bottle 750ml. @ home. [ As Logsdon Kili Wit ].Hazy - murky matt medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, citrus, yeast, tart, fruity, funky, coriander. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light acidic with a average to long duration, tart, citrus, fruity, yeast, coriander, funky. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to lively. [20160130]

Pours clear straw yellow first; gentle swirling of the bottle and now we have clouds. 

Hoppy spicy Wit here on the nose. Coriander very inviting. 

Coriander and other spices, something tangy in there. Especially in the finish; resembles lemon that is not too bitter; kinda like those containers at the grocery that resemble a lemon. 

What hoppiness I get compliments the spices rather than detracts. Another thing that I notice is a perceived by me hint of a honey presence. 

Medium body with prickly carbonation. 

This is really good.

Appearance: pours with a small white head, the beer is light gold, pretty clear
Aroma: has a bit of funk, some bread 
Taste: slightly sweet, strong banana, faint bitterness if you look for it, 
Palate: lively carbonation, frothy mouthfeel, slightly sweet aftertaste 
Overall: drinks like a good hefeweizen, nice banana and froth, pretty good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Willows Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is funky, grain funk. Taste is light Belgian yeast, chalky wheat funk, some floral spice. Purty gerd.

On tap at the tasting room - Pours hazy yellow with a white head. The aroma has lots of clean wheat, peach, limes, citrus and some light spice. It has a medium rich body with soft carbonation. The flavor starts with clean, but rich, wheat malt, some orange / lime, but spices are really low for the style. The finish has some herbs and dry wheat. Excellent.
really nice, and unique for the style - though style not something Id pay so much for a second time. Musty, lightly wild with citrus and spice.

From the 375 ml. bottle with a Best by 10/2015 date. Yellow, carbonated pour up to a short-lived white fizzy head. The aroma has a hint of coriander but the malts seemed kind of cardboard of musty cellar-like. Medium body. The taste has a touch of sour characters with all of those spicy malts.

375ml bottle pours hazy pale orange with a finger of head. Nose is wet grain, lemony citrus, light spice, cheese, cracker. Taste is tart (intentional?), crisp lemony grain, cracker spice, wet hay, yogurt, orange. Finishes tart, dry cracker, orange zest, light spice, wheat, hay.
Pale yellow colour with thin, lacy head. The aroma and flavour are incredibly fresh with a moderate but very drinkable tartness.

Bottle, Legacy. Hazy and pale yellow. Bubbly head. Aroma is a bit dusty...sitting too long on the yeast. This has more tartness than I would expect, and some plummy, blueberryish fruity depths. Finishes with a little bit of full maltiness.

Appearance: slightly hazy extremely straw with one finger of white head demising rapidly to a thick cap, moderate spotty lacing. (4/5) Aroma: dry yeasty funk, green apple, citrus, coriander. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter, light funky tart. (8/10) Palate: light body, moderate carbonation, crisp finish. (4/5)

What the heck is that? Nothing like other wits Ive had - not creamy, not white (at least not with a careful pour, trying to avoid the characteristic Logsdon gusher - but the last inch turned it white), lots of tart. Rather more like a wild or lambic than anything else, to be honest. Bright, crisp, and tart. Really nice and only slightly less interesting than the Logsdon Seizoen. (16/20)

Wow! Powerful nose of banana clove, orange, and sweetness, lemon. Nice golden color, great white lacing. Refreshing. Seltzery - wheat very present in the flavor. Sort of one dimensional flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy App

Gusher, which I guessed, so opened it in the sink. Huge white head.
Hazy pale yellow body with strong carbonation. Orangey mealy toffee
aroma with butterscotch notes. Lightly acidic butterscotch taste with
orangey mealy notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, mealy, slightly fizzy
mouthfeel. Dryish fruity orangey herbal aftertaste with mealy earthy
notes. A weird mix, this. Not sure if its a total disaster or just
odd. (0.75l bottle, from Kihoskh, Copenhagen.)

Bottle. Light hazy pale yellow with a medium sized frothy white head. Crisp nose with lemon, coriander and hay. Flavour is a different story, lots of yeasy fruit; banana, raspberries, cloves. Some hay, dry grass and white bread behind it. Light body, prickling carbonation, light sweet, little bitterness. Refreshing, but also somewhat thin and fizzy.
Filtered gold with light head. Aroma of malt, wheat, yeast then banana. Big flavours. Similar to aroma. Solid but not stellar.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is coriander, citrus, wheat. Thin mouth, strong citrus, brett, wheat, clean finish, really enjoyed this one.
Bottle at Christian. Pours yellow with light white head. Aroma and taste, citrus, fruity, yeast, funk, coriander. Slicky texture..
Early summer gettogether in RB Odense. Hazy golden with a small white head. Fruity aroma with white bread and a spicy touch. Sweet malty and fruity flavour with coriander in the aftertaste
Bottle @ Scheffel, Orla and Dolle - 3 men strong Odense Tasting. Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Sweet banana, wheat and sulphur. Spices. Wheat , banana and yeast. Soft and quite drinkable.

Outrageous wit. Maybe the best Ive ever had. Pours a bright golden yellow with a cloudy body, light sediment in suspension with a thick yellow hued head that dies down to a dense cap. The aroma is subtle and light as expected with hints of lemon peel, orange rind, coriander, grassy and floral notes all compacted with light estery notes. A bit sweet up front with a medium body, mild carbonation and a crisp, spicy flavour. Lemon rind, estery notes, exotic coriander and spice notes. Toasted wheat malts, light honey sweetness. A perfect beer for a hot day. A bit of bitterness on the finish with a light grassy hop that ends the profile. Very succinct and overall an incredibly well done wit.

This poured a hazy white to straw color with a white head. Aroma was of sugared oranges, light spice, some perm, and lemon Peel. Flavor was a great balance between citrus and spice and a hard to detect flavor. An awesome wit.

Bottle from Brewfest. Pale cloudy yellow orange with no real head or lace. Mild aroma of spice tangy wheat and banana. Tropical fruit sweetness wheaty bready tang with very sweet fruity and spicy finish. Tastes like it has grains of paradise in it, which I loathe. Nice medium-light body and mouthfeel. Carbo could be livelier. Pretty good, but I was expecting great.

On tap at Skuli, Reykjavik. Pours hazy straw with a small white head. Aroma of citrus and some farmhouse, spice and vanilla. Taste is light fruity & fresh citrus, moderate dry, good and refreshing wit.

Small bottle. A really cool label as usual for Logsdon. Pours a bright cloudy yellow color with a large white head. A big spicy and lemon nose. Soft yeasty tones, lemons, coriander, some more zesty lemon peel. Very soft and tasty. Solid.

stable dense ivorywhite head leaves lacing and foamhead. murky pale yellow colour. aroma is strawberry, apples like in cider, bit zesty, hint yoghurt. taste like aroma, slight peppery, floral. dry mouthfeel, rather thin body, very carbonated. bottle 75cl / bbf feb-2015

Cloudy mid-yellow. Decent,t tight white head. Lovely tart, spicy, lemony aroma with a lactic undertone. Medium carbonation and body. Rich, tart, white pepper and lactic upfront. Slight barnyard-iness. Good malt rich backbone. Slightly citric throughout. Followed by mineral and slightly tart aftertaste fade-out. Maybe lacking a bit more floral, but pleasant nonetheless.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Krone - hazy dark blond beer with a persistent white foam; fruity aroma (litchies, apples and mango), light spicy; pretty sour; medium-bodied, some sweetness; fruity and sourish aftertaste - quality and character

[3/2/15] Draught at Brouwers Cafe in Seattle. Cloudy yellow. Nice aroma with spice and citrus. Slightly sweetish and slightly tart flavor with wheat, citrus and some spiciness. Pretty light-bodied. A well-made refreshing Belgian Wit.
slightly tart, slight brett character, beautiful dry lemon-citrus experssions. truly a wonderful beer to drink.

Bottle, from Belmont Station, consumed at Endos house, 11/11/14.
Lightly hazed pale golden with a big old white covering.
Nose is fresh citrics, straw, lemon rind, bretty pangs, vanilla, light spice, mandarin.
Taste comprises passionfruit, mandarin, damp straw, light spice, corriander, vanilla.
Medium bodied, soft carbonaiton, semi drying close peppered with tangy citrics.
Solid wit.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: (Draught at Beer Temple, Amsterdam, 28 Feb 2015) Hazy yellow colour with frothy, white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of lemon, lime, white bread and grass. Malty, fruity taste with citrus, lemon peel, lime, white bread and a mild citric bitterness in the finish. Medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Really tasty witbier with a generous citric/lemon character. Nice one.

(En fût au Blind Lady Alehouse): De la coriandre, du blé acidulé, des zestes piquants dans un corps céréalier vigoureux et aérien. La finale est adéquatement sèche et propre, très solide dun bout à lautre.

On tap at the BeerTemple. Pale white gold pour with thin lacy white head. Aroma is grainy, really nice light spicy floral yeast notes. Taste is light, zesty, juicy with just a hint of spice, quite tasty. Palate is light, bone dry and refreshing. Good stuff.

Bottle purchased during my last Chicago trip ( maybe at Binnys). Great bright unfiltered gold color. Aroma is lemon zest, black pepper and a decent amount of wheat.
  
Has a soft carbonation level with a lighter, crisp refreshing crispness after the swallow. The balance of pepper, hops and lemon zest / lemon peel is well done. Good level of yeast as well with a slight tartness in the finish. Very nicely made.
Poured light hazy orange yellow with a frothy off white head. Aroma of lactose, light citrus and banana. Medium body, flavour of light spice, banana with a sweet and dry finish.
Draft at Beer Temple. Pours very hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast, dough, light herbs and weeds. Flavor is light sweet and over light acidic. Light bodied with light carbonation.
Tap at Brouwers Cafe, Seattle. Colour is cloudy yellow with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, citrus, wheat, some banana and malts.

February 8, 2015. Bottle at home, best before february 2016.
Hazy yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma is citrus, ripe fruits, brett, coriander. Taste us tart citrusy wit a light sweet fruity note and some spices. Finish is fruity and tart, light spicy, light bitter. Light to medium bodied, fizzy carbonation.

750 ml bottle- Pours hazy straw golden with a one finger head that i had to vigorously pour to get leaving a thin collar and some islands minutes later. Aroma is coriander, orange and lemon, spices, clean and refreshing. Taste is even better than the aroma, there seems to be lacto here, slightly funky and tart, lemony, grassy. Body is medium, carbonation is medium, good beer, very tasty and refreshing.

Tap. Clear golden body with a small, off-white head. Aroma of caramel, wheat, spicey notes and sour berries. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry and sour. Light bodied, oily to watery texture and lively carbonation. A nice and slightly sour Wheat.
Draught at Taphouse, København. Cloudy yellow - white head. Acid. Fresh citrus. Fruity. Light bitterness. Wild notes. Crispy. Ok green notes. Peppery notes.

Draught at Taphouse.
Clear yellow colored with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of citrus peel and flowers with notes of spices.
Fruity flavor of citrus peel and citrus.
Fruity finish.

Draft. An unclear golden beer with a lazing yellowish head. The aroma has notes of spices, wheat, dusty hops, and oranges. The flavor is sweet with notes of lemons, spices, and wheat, leading to a dry and slightly tart finish.

Draught @ Fermentoren, Århus. Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of wheat, yeast, brett, some spice, fruit, citrus, grapefruitpeel. Flavor is light sour, wheat, bretty, citrus. Medium body, lively carbonation, light sour finish. 290115

Tap @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, lemon, bretty and coriander. Flavor is medium sweet, moderate bitter and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 300115

Draught at Fermentoren, Aarhus. Hazy light golden body and a large white creamy head, Refreshing aroma of citrus, coriander, wheat and wild yeast. The taste is light to medium sweet, light bitter and sour.

Tap @ Fermentoren, Aarhus, 5.5%. Clear pale yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, wheat, yeast, coriander, fruit, spices, brett, little lemon and a little perfume. Flavour is mat, wheat, yeast, coriander, spices, little soap, medium sweet, lemon, brett, medium dry, hop, little acid, little sour and a little bitter.

This is a very genuine version of Belgian Witbier, even the appearance is true to style. Nice hazy, pale gold, nearly white pour with a thick white head that retains to the bottom of the glass and leaves nice lacing. Aroma of sweet malt, grain, citrus, and spice. Nice balance of sweet, sour, and bitter, with a creamy, refreshing palate. Not too hoppy, very nice, would repeat.

750 ml bottle. Hazed pale yellow, firm lasting white foam. Spicy yeasty aroma, some banana. Taste is fruity citrus, coriander, organically thin wheat, dissimilar warm spice, vegetal. Lively carbonation, light bodied, low hopped. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)

Bondurants nyc tap: pours pale yellow with a white head and no lacing. Aroma is citrus, some minor funk, and spice. Taste is sweet and almost a little bit on the sour side of life. Especially on the finish. It is a little on the sweet side, but not in a bad way.
Bottle. Pours a hazed gold with a medium sized white head. Soft musk and wheat on the nose. Medium bodied, wheat, musk, coriander. Nice and easy drinking. Gentle wheat and musk on the finish.

750ml bottle. Straw gold. White head. Aroma is grassy, floral, orange citrussy. Taste has a similar kind of fruitiness that I remember from Seizoen Bretta, in the realm of lime and lemon. Definitely tastes like a very similar yeast profile to that beer, and relies upon it much more than any added spices. Feels nice and balanced, carbonation a little high for me though. One of the better witbiers Ive had.
Hazy straw, fluff-fluff head. Papaya, lemon zest, pear, orange zest, spice, wheaty/grainy.

Bottle (75 cl) from Beergium, Belgium. Hazy greenish pale golden, large fluffy white head. Grainy and earthy aroma, some spici, citric notes. Light to mmedium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry, low bitterness.

Color dorado pálido, turbio, pero uniforme. Espuma blanca nívea densa e igualmente regular. Aromas frescos de cilantro, pan y fruta verde. Cuerpo ligero con carbonatación generosa, fruta fresca y verde de inicio, con ligera acidez, cilantro y toque cítrico. final seco equilibrado. Muy rica.

@ SBWF 2014: lett och frisk med tydlig smak av koriander. Lätt och ganska så enkel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

How: Draught.
Where: The Bishops Arms Vasagatan, Stockholm.
Appearance: Hazy golden colour with a white head.
Aroma: Sweet malt, fruit, citrus.
Body: Light to medium body, medium carbonation.
Flavour: Sweet malt, citrus, floral, some spices.

Draft @ Bishops Arms Vasagatan, Stockholm. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy weak peachy hoppy aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy yeasty finish.
Sample at SBWF 2014. Hazy orange with a white head. Quite light with hay, orange, apricot and some yeast. Also light notes of wheat. Easy to drink. An ok one.

Pours hazy yellow with low white head
Aromas has a lot of yeast (defected?), wheat, citrusy fruits
Taste has wheat, bread, hay, citrus
On tap at OConnors. Hazy bright yellow with white head. Aroma of wheat, pale malt and light coriander with light yeast noted. Taste is lightly sour, lots of coriander, wheat and pale malt.

Pours two fingers of head on a cloudy light straw colored body.
The aroma has honey and coriander upfront and dry grain in the background.
The taste is well balanced. Watery at first, honey sweetness in the middle, mild lemon bitter and finishes with a bracing tart.
The texture is crisp with moderate carbonation.
Its pretty good for a style that I dont usually enjoy.

On tap at the brewery. 

A: Pale straw color with a thin white head. 

N: Touch of lemon zest, wheat and peppercorn. Some orange and tangerine. Biscuit and barley. 

T: Soft bitterness, good level of barleyed sweetness.

M: Nice level of carbonation. Light body, sticks a bit to the palate. 

O: One of the better witbiers Ive had, and a beer that consistently surprises me because I dont expect to like it as much I usually do.

Pours cloudy orange with low white head. Aroma of honey, wheat, citrus, light cilantra. Taste is sweet, honey intense, followed by light citrus and cilantra in the finish. Body is light and smooth with soft carbonation.

Poura a lovely hazy golden orange with a medium creamy white head. Aromas of orange, farmhouse, citrus, honey, peach, apricot, spices. Taste is orange, citrus, apricot, funk, spices. Mouthfeel is very lively with high carbonation. Very good.

Bottle bought through craftbeer.se. Pours hazy pale yellow with a rather big frothy and fizzy white head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is tiny malty, tiny phenolic and tiny spicy with wheat crackers, hay, coriander, dry soil, minerals and lemon zest. Taste is very tiny sour, very tiny bitter and slightly phenolic with wheat crackers, baked pears, green apple skins, hay, dry soil, coriander, minerals and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is crisp, sparkling, slightly dry and light bodied. Finish is slightly phenolic with wheat crackers, pear skins, apple skins, hay, minerals and lemon zest. Surprisingly dull wit

Bottle courtesy of Andrew. Pours a bright hazy orange with active white lacing. Aroma is fresh grass, wheat, light pepper and additional spices. Mouthfeel is really nice - soft and delicate with just enough carbonation on the palate. Notes of citrus fruit, wheat, light farm character, spice and fresh cut grass. Really nice, fresh dry wit.
On draught at Solog Festival. Hazy yellow color. Aroma is light yeast, coriander, and orange peel. Taste is similar, very light flavorful and refreshing.

750 ml bottle poured a hazy gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, yeast, spice and light citrus. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of wheat, yeast, spice and a hint of citrus with a crisp dry finish.

Thought this was a saison initially so I poured it into a tulip. 
Only after I poured most of it unto this glass I found out its a witbier. Drat! Next time, proper glassware. 
From this session, here are my findings. 
The appearance was a nice looking hazy golden yellow to orange color with a thin half finger-ed white foamy head that concaves rather nicely leaving a nice clingy foaminess all around. 
The smell was absolutely amazing with a nice lemon to orange fruitiness really sweet and strong with such a nice spicy coriander and clove - like allocation in the blend. 
The taste took all of those previously mentioned flavors and combined them rather nicely. 
On the palate, this one sat right at a medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation finishes fairly smooth with a nice creaminess coating my tongue. The carbonation is there but not too much. 
Overall, hot damn, I was skeptical of the price but being my first one by Logsdon, I had to jump. Oh yeah, bottle number is 16985, best if enjoyed by 12/2014. This was so worth the $15. I can only imagine how it would be if I would have put it in proper glassware.
Spice comes through more than a bit. I like the spikey carbonation. I think that carbonation helps this beer pair with more foods than a typical wit. Very nice!
Bottle, shared at RBAG 2014. Very hazy yellow with a lasting white head. Aroma is orange rind and light plastic. Dry pithy citrus and wheat, clean dry finish. Refreshing.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Fat på brewdog - doftar surt och smakar extremt sött med en smygande beska. Väldig ljus och grumlig.
Tap @ Brewdog Göteborg. Hel del syrlighet i aromen och smaken. Väldigt frisk.

Draught at Brewdog Bar, Göteborg. Sourish wheat aroma, grassy, grapes, raisins, figs, salty, slightly vinous. Sourish citrus flavor, cream, raisins, hay, sweetish, figs, grapes, some floral notes. Sourish salty finish with grapes and hay. Decent beer.
On tap at brewdog GBG. Pours pale yellow with a small white head. Smells canned fruit, a bit sweet hoppy. Tastes sour fruity hoppy, bitter sweet and canned fruit with a bitter sweet finish.
Yellow with white head, cloudy,sour dough in the aroma. High in citrus, banana hint of malt, mild metalic bitterness in the aftertaste. High in carbon.

Pours a pale yellow with a one finger white head with a little lacing. Aroma is of lemon zest, sour fruits, belgian yeast, wheat bread, pepper, spicy grassy hops, and some spices. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma with a notes of lemon, pepper, spices, wheat bread, grassy hops, and some mild brett. Has a medium-light body with a creamy mouthfeel and a dry, slightly bitter, medium, refreshing finish. Overall, a excellent witbier that is very refreshing and drinkable, and is pretty complex for the style.

Pours bright clear yellow into a tulip. Bright white head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Citrus, bread and hay aromas. Crisp with marshmallow and wheat upfront turning to mild citrus in the medium length finish.

On draught at Higgins - pours cloudy golden with small white head. Nose of yeast and cloves. Taste of cloves, yeast, and grass. Would be perfect summer beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours yellow with a big frothy to creamy head that shrinks to a thin ring and good lace. aroma of coriander, citrus and pine. Lightly sweet before turning lightly sour with no bitterness to be found. Light to medium body with way too much carbonation. I let it sit for 30 minutes and the carbonation diminished to a more manageable level. Flavors of sour citrus and light honey. Very drinkable and interesting.

750 ml bottle. Aroma consists of dusty old bretty basements, lemon peel, coriander, cotton candy. Pours a pale pale yellow with a large white soapy head with great retention. Taste starts out lightly sweet before turning sour (6/10 on a sour scale) and acidic, finishing dry. Mouthfeel is a bit too carbonated for me--its a lot like champagne, one of my least favorite alcoholic drinks. Flavor and aroma are great, though. This would be fantastic if it was more finely carbonated--as such, its merely good.

An interesting, but pretty one note wit. Pours an ugly clear yellow with a light white head. Smells and tastes of lemon and only lemon. Intense. Had on tap at Bottles.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Ours cloudy gold, medium white head, nice lacing. Aroma is wheat, fruity, just a touch of funk. Flavor follows, coriander and lemon, funk, wheat. Light sweet, light tart, fairly spiced. Light body, bit of warming.
On draft at the icelandic beer festival. Fruity aroma and some spices that I couldnt figure out. Murky yellow. Extremely refreshing.
Hazy yellow, firm head. Loads of funk in the aroma, tart and acidic, funky zesty finish

Aroma: Corriander, Oranges, Zesty

Appaearance: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

Taste: Corriander, Bright Oranges, Mild Wheat

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet

Dude serious fluffy white head. Flavor is light citrus and spice. Very dry and slightly sweet. Good toned down wheat body letting the spice and citrus come through more strongly. Tasty and refreshing.
Gold, slight haze, fluffy white head. Aroma of grainy malt, spice. Flavor of wheat malt, earthy spice, herbal notes, tangy tartness, a little citrus, dry finish.

Sampled from bottle in Florida on January 23, 2014.Marked 5% ABV and apparently about a year old.Hazy yellow color, white head. SWeet, fruity scent. Sweet, citrus taste. Sweet aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.

Bottle: Poured a super pale yellow color ale with a very large foamy head with perfect retention and incredible lacing. Aroma of light coriander with loads of dry Bretty notes with some wheat malt notes also noticeable. Taste is also dominated by a mix of coriander, wheat malt with loads of dry Brett notes. Body is light with incredible carbonation. Very refreshing with bone dry finish.
Bottle courtesy of Ed. Pours a murky pale yellow fluffy white head. Nose of coriander, wheat, spice. Medium body, fairly dry

750ml bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy golden with a lacy, white head. Aroma of spicy yeast, some light fruits, some pale malts, some wheat, a little bitterness, and light spices. Flavor the same. Average to lighter texture. A decent witbier but it could be better.

In short: A citric witbier of superior quality with a nice farmhouse character.
How: Bottle 750ml, consumed relatively fresh not long after purchase.
The look: Cloudy pale yellow body topped by a medium white head with medium retention.
In long: Nose is pleasantly musky and somewhat farmhouse over banana esters. Taste offers a lot of wheat that actually taste like sundried straw. There is also fresh bananas, a bite in a fluffy lemony pastry, a slice of lime, green herds, citric hops, mild spiciness. For a beer that says it is brewed using coriander on the label, it sure didnt feel very corianderized. Lively carbonation and the strong yeast presence increased the foamy mouthfeel. This is no your girly witbier. This is along the lines of a St. Bernardus Blanche as a top example of this usually boring style. I;m really digging this brewery. I really have a love-hate relationship with this brewery, I love drinking Logsdon beers and I hate not having any Logsdon beers to drink.
Bottle exploded all over my counter thanks to Homer321. Huge gusher. Pours 90% head, 10% beer. Aroma is light citrus, wheat malt. Flavor is light metallic, light wheat character, citrusy.

Best by June, 2013

Pours like a pilsner, light yellow straw color with loose, bone white foam. Brilliant clarity - unusual for the style. Smells of grain, wet dog, paper, some lemon rind, a little metal and more wet dog. Initial flavor is funky, extra funky, some coriander and a little bit of that sweet classic wit yeast flavor. Just a touch of banana on the finish. Medium on thin for the style with moderate carb and a wet finish. This is intriguing, the nose is interesting as is the flavor, Id rather it were labeled a farmhouse blond or something as it doesnt really fit into any style.

Bottle. Medium-sharp zesty nose, with some sweet spice and sugar. Bright straw color. Fruit and vegetables / light pickles and lemon / finish is very mild with a light tanginess. Thin-medium body, soft and gentle on the palate. Smooth and light, with a pleasant variety of flavors.

Smell is pepper, pears, pickles.
Pours a big head.
Taste is peppers, beats, little vinegar, drinking a salad. Pickley. Green veggies. Orange.

At a tasting at KyotoLeftys place. This & the Tindved were the most unique beers of the night. A lightly cloudy straw gold pour with a peppery, pear, celery & vinegar/tsukemono aroma. The light body contains a sour, sweet beets & pickles flavor. Interesting but probably an acquired taste.

Bottled. Cloudy pastel yellow, fine low head. Pineapple, spice, lemon, Interesting, a bit weird spicing. Sweet, with tangy tinge, lemon, berries, soap, spice. Interesti fruit flavors. A bit too much spice. Pears, apples. Peppery, dry, slightly vegatal finish, celery. Light pickles.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, best before 2/2014. Big gusher upon opening, but didnt lose any of it. Pours very hazy golden amber color with a 3 finger dense and rocky white head with incredible retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick foamy lacing clings around the glass, with a large amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big lemon, pear, apple, apricot, grape, coriander, clove, pepper, wheat, bread, oats, herbal, grass, musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good complexity and balance of fruity/spicy yeast ester and malt notes; with good strength. Taste of lemon, pear, apple, apricot, grape, coriander, wheat, bread, oats, clove, pepper, herbal, grass, musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of lemon, apricot, light fruits, coriander, pepper, clove, wheat, bread, oats, herbal, grass, light funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, malt, and spice flavors; with a great malt/spiciness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with very smooth, crisp, fairly creamy, and moderately prickly mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a really excellent witbier! All around great complexity, balance, and robustness of flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Sample at the Ale Wine & Spirits beer tasting on 10/24/2013: Pours a hazy golden color with a medium thin foamy white head that dissipates steadily to a wispy film. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of banana, yeast and coriander. Light-bodied with flavors of spiced wheat, bananas and earthy yeast. The finish is sweet with a spice and zesty citrus aftertaste. Decent overall.

750ml bottle. Cloudy bright orange with a fizzy white head. Aroma of musty earth, orange rind wheat, spice and hay. Flavor is zesty spicy esters, light citrus tartness and crisp wheat malt. Light body with lively carbonation. Nice take on a Witbier, lots of citrus and earthiness, very refreshing.

Bottle. Pours a foggy golden color with a nice, white head. Strong banana aroma with wheat and barley. Very, very nice. Smooth wheat flavor with banana and lemon zest. A complete beer that doest really need any tinkering. One of the best wheat beers I have had.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a good white head that leaves nice lacing patterns. Aroma is spicy and sour-ish. Definitely some coriander in there. Taste is fruity, spicy and dusty. Some nice tropical notes from the brett in there too. Citrusy and lightly tart. Carbonation level is high and mouthfeel is creamy. Light bodied and quaffable. Fun and refreshing, a nice way to start my discovery of Logsdons product!

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by mathieuc, thanks! Hazy yellow with a huge foamy white head and good lacing. Aroma is very yeasty with citrus, light spices and light sweetness notes. Taste is yeast with light spices, some citrusy notes and brettanomyces. Light body. Fizzy carbonation. Slightly dry finish. Not too heavy on spices, which is really good. Super drinkable. One of the best Witbier Ive tried so far.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours hazy blond with high white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of yeast, bananas, coriander, citrus, slight diaper plastic. Taste is of citrus, spices, yeast. Palate: Light body. Somewhat high carb. Overall: Good. Very yeasty. Tasty,

bottle shared by mathieuc, thanks bro. pours hazy almost cloudy pale yellow with a small but nice and somewhat persistent white cap, very nice lacing patterns. dusty yeastiness, quite spicy but not quite discernable (african) spices, fresh wheat, pils, farmhouse malts, tropicalness, low but present funk, coriander hints, as in not-too-much-of-it-like-so-many-wits, very hint of metal. lively carbonation - almost foamy, light body, dry herbal-grassy-spicy finish. not your classic wit for sure. much enjoyed!

Bottle. Pours bright hazy gold with a huge gusher head. Aroma is citrus, earthy funk and a touch of honey. Taste amplifies the citrus and honey and relegates the funk to some musty earthiness on the finish. Medium mouthfeel with a little too much carbonation. This is very enjoyable.

Appearance: deep orange gold pour with a thick, electric white head; toward the end of the bottle, the pour looked more like rather unappealing caramel pudding	due to all the extra floaties.  Aroma: citrus, banana, coriander, cracked wheat, and FUNKFUNKFUNKFUNK.  Taste: orange zest, pineapple, coriander, white pepper, mineral water, slightly floral honey, and FUNKFUNKFUNKFUNK.  Finish: dry as champagne, with some citrus and, of course, FUNK hanging around at the end.  Notes: 	This is a very good witbier. Definitely taken in a slightly new direction due to what must be brettanomyces to bring this level of horseblankety, bandaidy, musty farmhouse funk. Nevertheless, the palate was excellent and the flavors and aroma were nice.   Bottle from the Rare Beer Club.

Hazy golden pour. Good size head. Citrus/funky aroma, very slight spice, lemon, wheat. A lot more coriander and funk while im drinking this. Lemon, horseblanket, yeast, wheat, grass. Lighter body. Recommended if you like a bit of funk.

Hazy golden, moderate head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is funky with notes of citrus, funk, oat, bread, spice, apple. The aroma isnt reminiscent of your typical wit, its way more funkdafied. Not sure it works. Medium bodied, funky, lightly spicy. Interesting take on the style, they didnt nail it, but if they did it would be my absolute favorite wit.

Bottle to pint glass
Bananas, horse blanket, and lemons. Cloudy yellow, no head...ugly. Slight lemon, yeasty, maybe a touch of Brett.

This is how you do a Wit right. Just fantastic creamy lactose richness with zesty citrus rind and spices. The brett and subtle tartness just dry out the finish and add to the complexity. Could drink this one all day.
Bottle - Grassy, lemon, horse blanket and coriander. Pale cloudy yellow with a thin head. Mellow grains, lemon and a bit of yeast. Nice and understated.

On tap @ Noble Fir. Pours heavily cloudy pale orange with very thin head that disappears quickly. Aroma is sweet floral citrus and dry spice. Taste is clean thin pale malt, mild dry citrus notes, wheat notes, and slightly tart finish. A bit less spicy than many wits, but no less flavorful.
Delicious! Very refreshing and light, sour funk, lemony, full of flavor. This is great.

750 ml bottle courtesy of breaks808. Thanks, dude. Poured upon arriving home from the weekend and settling down. Pours a straw golden hue, cereal yellow, slight haziness, but near transparent. Light and yellow, a cakey bright white head atop dies to a firm filmy layer, sticks around and laces well. Vibrant carbonation. Aromas show banana and fruity ester, gentle Belgian yeast grows, a touch spicy with straw, bread, and gentle coriander. Touches of oat, bread, a dry earthy hop element comes on as it warms and settles. Banana, apple, gentle lemon peel. Initial is a decent tartness up front, lemony and gentle tartness mix with bready malts, fairly clean and light cereal element, dry straw and gentle yeastiness. A firm fruity presence. Middle is still tart, firm tart apple, bit of banana and lemon elements still intertwine. Some gentle funk and fuzzy dryness as we round the corner, decent straw, grass, and mellow spiciness mix with a young but definitely present bretty house feel. Finish is light, effervescent, and dry. That fruity tart feel up front really grabs me, a more dry and clean finish, a bit bready and earthy, really is my thing. You can find a lot of messy sweeter offerings in the style and a load more coriander bombs. This is none of those. Quite a nice beer here.

Pours a hazy light golden almost straw color with a fizzy two finger head. Lots of spicy complex yeast notes mingle with subdued fruit... touches of lemon zest, kiwi and pineapple. Great spritzy mouthfeel with a soft pear backdrop and a clean crisp slightly grassy and funky finish.

750ml capped bottle pours a light straw color with a huge white head that retains well and leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is grains and light fruits with a hint of spice. Taste is a spicy hop bitterness with a grainy malt sweetness and a dry yeasty finish. Light to medium body with generous carbonation. A nicely done witbier that is definitely worth trying.
Cloudy yellow pour, big white head. Nice hops, great yeast, spice, crackers, light orange orange notes.

Bottle. Its bready and yeasty in the aroma, with plenty of fruity esters, a little wheat grain, and some spices. The pour is a golden-orange color with a thick fluffy white head. A small ring of lace clings to the glass after nearly each sip. Sweet citrus fruity flavors that combine with coriander spice, funky bready yeast, and barnyard straw notes. Dry and fizzy finish. Good beer. Its refreshing and easy to drink, but with good complexity behind it, so far from boring.

Im usually a sucker for a good wit. This one was pretty good, but fell short of my lofty expectations. (Ive loved every thing else Ive had from Logsdon so far) It pours a nice pale yellow with a white head. The aroma has very bright, fresh lemony bread, wheat and coriander. The flavor is mildly tart (not acidic) with some orange fruity, coriander, bread crust and some mild lemon in the finish. This one fell a little short on the palate. It didnt have the light, airy feel that I love so much from the top examples of this style. Still a very good beer though.

Bottle-purchased at Whole Foods in Chandler, AZ May 2012.  Pours lightly hazy goldish yellow hue with a fluffy white head with some sudsy lacing on one side of the glass.  not alot of carbonation yet still has good head retention.  nose is funky, dusty, estery (barnyard, funk, gymsock, with notes of pepper, corriander and lite zest).  very nice nose-not what i was expecting being a wit but for this brewery, they do alot of different stuff with their beers.  flavors are very funky, dusty as well with notes of sourness, lemon, corriander, with a ton of dusty esters.  a very funky wit here, verging on a lite saison if you ask me.  finish is lightly sour with quite a bit of dryness to it with lingering peppery notes.  this is a world class wit if you ask me.  If you find it, definately get it!

Thanks to Jcr. Pours creamy pale yellow. Strong lace. Spicy phenols, earthy spices, must, some citrus. Flavor is citrus, must, earthy spice.  Weidly earthy and musty but without Brett. very interesting. crisp carbonation. Really nice.
Bottle.  A yellow color with a full foamy white head.  A farmhouse dusty aroma with plenty of citrus, lemon, and wheat aromas.  It has a dry finish with lingering citrus.
750ml bottle pours light yellow gold with frothy white head. Lemon zest aroma. Lemon and orange wheat taste.
On tap at alibi. Cloudy yellow. Smells of lemon and wet dog. Greatly fresh taste of lemon, hops and yeast.

Draft. Light golden body. Foamy, white head. Aroma of lemon, orange, spices, coriander, grains of paradise, dough, bread, light earthiness. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/creamy texture, soft carbonation. Slight mustiness in the flavor along with some tartness. Citrus flavors and a slight husky graininess, but not much. Different and tasty.

Bottle. Pours hazy straw-yellow, rocky white head. No lacing whatsoever. Aroma of light fruits, banana, coriander. Floral. Mineral in the taste, along with fruit and earthiness. Tastes somehow salty? Lively carb, light body, crisp dry finish. overall: saisony wit - alright, but not going to rush out to get it again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle with Court, Bri, and Simon in harisburg, pours murky yellow gold with medium to large white head, good lacing. Aromas and taste of belgain yeast, soap, lemons, light coriander, faint hops, light rust, mineral water, cotton, salt, and earth. Maybe a tad bit of oxidation but didnt detract from the flavors, minimal. Nice

Bottle: &nbsp Somewhat of a dirty straw, yellowish, not too pale like most wits, heavy in haziness tho, with a 

moderate frothy off-white head and spotty lacing. &nbsp Wheaty nose, subtle spices, a little sulphur and farty smells. &nbsp 

At first it seemed a little spicy, but its not corriander or orange peel thats there, its a slight lavendar farty soap or 

something. &nbsp Not as farty on the tongue, a bit more spicy but in a floral and lavendar sense. &nbsp This is somewhat of 

an odd duck for a Witbier because its not your citrusy/corriander sort of flavor. &nbsp Definitely a Wheat beer, but spicy in 

some floral/soapy sort of sense. &nbsp Entertaining, but at $10, not so entertaining. &nbsp Meh, wished it were more 

traditional.

750mL thanks to cavemanlawyer. Pours glowing, full haze bright straw with massive white foam. Good retention and spotty lacing. Nose is slightly phenolic, fresh flowers and pollen, laundry dryer sheets. Taste is very light, super aerated with hints of crackery rustic grain. Finishes with sourdough biscuit and mild cream. Very refreshing. Just enough density to not come off as "thin."

Bottle with a best before date of 06/2013. Pours with a hazy golden yellow hued body and a medium sized foamy white head that slowly fades. Aromas are very doughy, fresh baked bread, wheat, floral, grainy, medium esters, toasted coriander, grains of paradise, richly spiced. Citrusy, some candied orange peel. Earthy. Flavors are doughy, grainy, malty, wheat. Quite yeasty, with further esters and mild phenols. Black pepper. Almost a touch metallic. Light acidity. Lightly funky spice or phenol and the back end. Low notes of coriander and citrus. Pretty refreshing. Good.

Somewhat full bodied for the style with very lively carbonation. Slightly acidic finish.

Poured from a 750ml bottle. Pours straw and cloudy. Slight tartness, doughy, a touch skunky, grainy, wheat, hint of citrus. This bottle may be a bit oxidized. A solid beer with some slight off flavors.

On tap at Ale Arsenal. Subtle lemon and biscuit aroma with grassy undertones. Pours a hazy light yellow with a white head if minuscule bubbles leaving slight trails on the glass and a collar of head. Taste is refreshing with lemon, slight lime, and light cracker malt. Slight bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel makes this a perfect beer for a warm early summer day. Would pair nicely with grilled citrus shrimp.

750ml bottle from Belmont Station, split with my bride.  Pours a cloudy yellow color with a white head and a little lacing.  Aroma is all wheat beer, banana, clove, bread.  Light to medium on the palate with light carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, bready, yeasty, some lemony citrus, with a light, yeasty finish.  A nice wit.

Bottle KW4838. Best by 04/2013. 

Pours a pale, hazy gold topped with an enormous mound of fine white bubbles. Pretty much spot on for the style. Clumps of bubbles cling to the walls of the glass.

It mostly smells of clean, doughy wheat. I think theres some spicing, coriander and orange or lemon peel, in the mix, but its pretty far in the background. Lightly grassy hops. Theres a hint of funk and cleanly earthy yeast. A touch of band-aid. Its just an awfully light aroma. Very clean and subtle for the style.

The taste is similarly clean. Its mildly dry. Theres still a fresh, sweet wheat flavor, but it sits lightly on the palate and doesnt linger. Some earthy funk from the yeast, particularly in the finish. More citrus and coriander. Apples, apricots, green grapes. Tasty.

Light, pleasant mouthfeel. I enjoy the even drier wits, like Anchorage Whiteout, but this is just a very nice beer to drink. It goes down smoothly. Carbonation is fine, plentiful and gentle. 

This is a nice witbier. Its well made and drinkable. Judging by other reviews, it seems that the spicing isnt quite dialed in. I like this milder version, though. It comes off rather saison-like, which as someone who prefers saisons to wits, I dont mind. Anywho, its a good beer.

Bottle - Hazy golden pour with a soapy, filmy white head. Nose is stone fruit, pear, coriander, subtle citrus peel, and a bit of tart funk. Mmm...very pungent and fresh nose. The taste is equally as good. It has a light gueuze funk to it with subtle spiciness, fruity, dry malt, and a touch of stale, herbal hops on the finish. Fluffy body, thin and bubbly with ample carbonation. Tastes like a saison/gueuze/wit hybrid. Glorious.

Bottle number kw9574 best by 6/2013. Pour has a very light straw color and a one finger white head. Aroma has wheat, banana yeast, light spicy hops, and a slight tartness. Mouth feel is light and the carbonation medium. Flavor has wheat, light yeast, some hops, and a clean finish.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, hazy orange pour with nice lacy white head, aroma brought notes of orange peel, coriander, touch of earth, grain, nice slight funk, tartness from the fruit, hints of pineapple, peach, nice.  Taste is a nice refreshing mix of tart stone fruits, some peach and apricot, into lemon, biscuit, bready notes, slight coriander into earth, orange, and a slight tart note, finsihing dry, clean.  Nicely done.

Bottle in Mesa. Pours a cloudy yellow appearance with a foamy white head. Spicy yeasty, pineapple, tropical fruity, kiwi, sweet wheat aroma. Tangy, kiwi, big zesty tropical fruity, coriander, a bit funky, tart flavor. Really delicious.

750 ml bottle from bev4less. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a medium white head that has fair retention. The aroma is mild with dust, light citrus, indistinct spices and some mild funkiness. The flavor features lemons, mild spices, breads, nutty hops and a neutral malt base. The palate is full and creamy smooth with soft carbonation. Finishes clean and dry. Overall:  Very well done wit, very tasty.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown best by June 2013 bottle poured into a weizen glass.  Pours cloudy golden with big fluffy white head.  Fluffy white lacing, medium body, well carbonated, and coriander aroma.  Taste is rich estery, some coriander, and a hint of lemon.  Good wit.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 A: Clear light amber with a fluffy whit head, got hazier every time I pour from the bottle. S: Raw wheat, spices, yeast and coriander. T: Wheat, spices, coriander, some funky yeast, earthy, caramel malt, and some fruity hops. M: Crispy with a nice carbonation to in and some bitterness. O: This is a very refreshing brew, well balance and easy to drink but it lacks some of that belgian funky yeast that I like in wit beers. Sure it has great flavors but it is also just watery.

Bottle provided by Todd, this is my final Logsdon tick!  Pours a murky pineapple juice looking color. It has a half fingers worth of soapy white head, that dissipates rather quickly. A typical wit nose to this with a healthy dose of tropical fruit and clove. I imagine this is the yeast at play, but it is incredible pleasant. The flavor is dry, clove, light wit, light tartness, and some very light fruitiness. Light mouthfeel, light carbonation, light tartness, and a short finish.

(26oz bottle) Purchased at the Strath for $12.90. Pours a lofty white head atop a clouded yellow body. Nose of vanilla, banana, yeast and coriander. The flavours are more citrus and white pepper. Enjoyable but I have preferential local beers from Lighthouse and Driftwood I'd have before this. 

--- reviewed on RateBeer.com

Bottle from 16 Tons, Eugene. Pours slightly cloudy golden color, fair amount of head. Aroma is sightly doughy, maybe a bit of spice.Body is medium, smooth and just a bit lively. Finish is crisp, bright and with just the tiniest hint of citrus from the hops. Really a lovely example of the style.
Light 10 karat/brass colored pour with tons of coriander, wheat, grain, bread, yeast, spice, pepper, and buttermilk biscuit.  A nice dose of citrus.  Really solid...specifically for the style.

Pour is a lemonaide blonde with a large white head.  Aroma is a corriander spice with some citrus.  Flavor is citrus zestyness with some wheat malt base.  Finish is dry with a little pear juice.  A decent no frills wit beer.  Thin but quenching even in winter.

750 mL bottle. Light gold color with a big, foamy, white head. The aroma is biscuity yeast, lime, coriander, and a light tin note. Citrusy sweetness, with a little tart and bitter note in the finish. Light body, sticky, acidic, and a little buttery. Overall, this is a light, crisp, and remarkably flavorful witbier.

750mL pours opaque pale gold with a thin white head of foam. The aroma delivers up apples, pears, hay, a mild yeastiness and a light citrus like tartness. The taste is semi bright with sweet light skinned fruit notes like apples and pears as well as a more meadowy hay like sensation. Behind those notes is a bit of yeastiness and crisp yet modest in strength tart citrus. This is refreshing and rich all at the same time. Nice!
750 ml bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy gold with light head. Aromas of yeast, plastic (bandaids), and melons. Flavors of honey, clamato juice, white pepper, and light malts. Quite interesting.

Draught at St. Augustines, VancouverCloudy pale blond color; medium sized head. The aroma is spicy, dry; some plastic. The mouthfeel is lean, very dry, with an evident lemony and spicy character, although the spice profile is different than the usual Wit or Weisse; correct bitterness.Refreshing.
Very balanced beer with a nice opening, but the finish was a bit musky for my liking. I would have like to have tasted more corriander and spice.

This is how you do a Wit right.  Just fantastic creamy lactose richness with zesty citrus rind and spices.  The brett and subtle tartness just dry out the finish and add to the complexity.  Could drink this one all day.

Bottle at home with friends. Pour is hazy lemon with a frothy white head that quickly dissipated. Straw, yeast, biscuit, light spice, orange peel, and soap in the aroma. Taste is big lemon zest, straw, somewhat bland, yeast, biscuit, and fruit peel with a crisp, dry lingering finish. Thin body with fizzy carbonation. Pretty good wit, but somewhat one-dimensional, still pretty tasty.
Wow this I awesome, lightly tart and orangey, great wit best so far.  Wish I had a florence.
Straw colored pour, lemon pledge like aroma, slight band aid lemon sugar. Light tartness, herbal, weird peanut in the finish. Citrusy tart finish.
Bottle, Thx mike!  Hazy light white, thin head.  Nose is unpleasant sweat/funk at first giving way to lemon & coriander.  Flavor is far nicer - wheat, lemon, funk, clean finish.

750 ml bottle purchased online at Letspour.com.  The pour is a hazed yellow, with a smallish white head.  The aroma is a strong lemongrass, along with soft musty yeast, and the wheat grain. The taste is initially the wheat grain, turning to the spice of the coriander and lemongrass, and finishing with the pronounced musty, hint of funk, yeast.  Quite full flavored, perhaps a bit heavy on coriander and lemongrass for my tastes. The palate is light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, and a lingering yeasty after taste.  Nice Wit, everything I have had from Logsdon has had a lot of character.

A soft pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a four-finger thick, rim topping, pale tan colored head that leaves lots of thick lacing on the sides of my glass. The beer is a nice gold color, with lots of streaming carbonation, that shows a brilliantly clear, pretty yellow-gold hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells of clean bright, tropical citrus that is backed by a musty, slightly white pepper like character, and a touch of pale grain character.

Effervescent, dry, but with some sweetness, as well as a clean citrus character, some bitter herbal notes, and a hint of tartness. The bitterness is actually fairly pronounced for a Wit beer. Lots of woody, herbal notes, a touch of pine, spruce tip like flavors, a touch of Meyer Lemon, and a dry tropical fruit like note are quite noticeable here. The body has a fullness to it that seems to be contributed by the wheat, but this is quite light and quaffable. The finish has a touch of musty spiciness to it as well as a carbonic bite, and musty grain character. The grain character here has a tart wheat flavor to it, a wholesome straw like note, even some green grassiness, and perhaps a hint of soda cracker to it. The second pour with some yeast in it accentuates a raw wheat dough character as well as softening and muting the citrus / fruit character here, as well as the bitter bite. The peppery spice character gets nasal with a musty, spicy note that makes my nose itch as the bee warms up.

Definitely a nice Wit; I am quite impressed that the citrus character was mostly achieved by the hop character, I assume there is some grains of paradise used here that contributes to the citrus character as well as the soft, musty, woody character, and definitely a soft spiciness in the finish.

Bottle. Pours pale yellow with a slight haze and a short white head. The head leaves a thin film and a spotty lace. Bright spiced aroma. Has an unusual edge to it. Hot asian entree and wintergreen gum. Could be the African element. The flavor is tart and a little salty. Light body, thin-creamy texture, good carbonation, and a dry, crisp finish.

Hazy golden-yellow body, large white head, streaky lacing.  Lemon zest, wheat, citric hops, coriander, mild yeast presence.  Medium to light bodied, zippy carbonation, light bitterness, refreshing dry finish. A nice American take on the Belgian White.
bottle,thanks to bu11zeye, yellow colored pour with some lemony spice aromas, flavor is thin, grainy, lemon , pepper

bottle with a big thanks to ruddbud.    notes of creamy, soft wet grass and muddled basil herb twang.      slight touch of lemon acidity.     soft pear yeast.   dry. complex tasty clean well made beer.  really nice all around.   i like it!

Lustrous pale orange pour with a brimming, silky head and really nice lacing left behind. Nose is strong tangerine and mild citric tartness, settling nicely into a dry and hoppy impression overall. Good fuckin start for a wit! Prickly mouthfeel is nice, and theres an interesting little bite on the palate that I reckon is there from the spice. That element is very, very understated in the taste but works well to complement the bitter rind and hops at the beers core, rounded out as a whole by those lovely fruity notes. Pretty damn good.

(750ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) clear gold, fine white bubbles that last. Nose of wheat, coriander, clean, white pepper, Melba toast, rye. Taste of pepper, rye, spicy, wheat. Medium body, very carbonated and fairly dry.
Bottle at the Funky 8, Brooklyn, NYC. A very nice wit. Well balanced, mellow spice character, not too sugary. Crisp, fairly refreshing. Not bad at all.

A - Pours an almost clear golden yellow with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of wheat, grains, coriander, lemon zest, citrus hop, Belgian yeast, and some funk.

T - Starts off with some wheat, lemon zest, citrus hop, and coriander. Through the middle, some Belgian yeast and funk comes through with a bit of bready grains and some more spice and pepper. The finish is a mix of Belgian yeast, funk, spices, lemon zest, and coriander.

M - Medium-minus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry and lightly funky finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced Witbier with some good complexity. Great yeast flavor and funk.

Pours a two finger white head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace. Murky light amber color, ton of yeast left in bottle. Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Lemon and yeast nose and flavor is tart lemon, some yeast and hints of coriander. Expensive at $19.95 (includes a glass) for a 750ml bottle from Made in Oregon Portland, Or.
A delicious wit with sweet malts and warming body, good yeast flavors, overall clean and crisp.

Very drinkable Wit style beer. Nice mellow balance between the coriander and the citrus elements. Second best Wit beer so far in the Oregon Brewers Fest. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle conditioned 750ml. glowing hazed gold body with a tall-building white head of foamy soap-like bubbles and patchy thick lacing.  well damn, if that doesnt smell nice...salty perfume esters, fresh orange and lemon juices and a touch of exotic spices or saffron.  medium-light body with chewy wheat and lightly husky grains.  soft and creamy carbonation with mild citrus juice flavor, medium acid, a lightly chewy texture late and a mild, silky wheat and cream finish.  damn nice.

750, capped. Gorgeous packaging. Take this beer to a party without a doubt. Pours a murky burnished medium gold with a surging, frothy, dense platinum blond head. Lemons, hay, wet grass, and a little bit of barnyardy funk in the background on the nose. Very appealing and refreshing, especially on a warm day, with plenty of power and dimension even straight from a cold fridge. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Lemons and maybe a bit of white chocolate on the mid palate. Flavors dont quite deliver the dimensionality promised by the nose, but theyre certainly not far off the mark. This is a delicious and easy-drinking wit.

Bottle from City Beer. Pours clear yellow with a huge white head and a banana aroma. There is a hearty wheat flavor with some citrus and lots of spice left on the palate. The particular spices used are a bit unusual for a witbier and make this brew somewhat unique.

750mL bottle, Bottle No. KW 3345, Best enjoyed by 01/2013 from Olive Tree Market in OB for $10.99, Or OB Quik Stop for $16.99. Really? Only 9 ratings so far? Ive seen this, unmoving on the shelves for at least a few months.  Maybe their price point is a little high for a pretty much unknown brewery.  Hazy pale straw with a 1 1/2 finger white head, fades to a lasting thick film for the duration, and easily roused to a larger, more pretty head.  Aroma has the same yeasty earthy rustic-ness as their Seizoen, with a bit stronger wheat notes and pear.  There is also some definite coriander.  Flavor continues with the earthy, almost manure-ish rustic nature of what seems to be par for Logsdon beers.  Whereas most wits tend to have a much brighter quality to them, this aforementioned characteristic keeps it from becoming so.  By no means is this necessarily bad, but it does take some getting used to. Luckily for me, it just took most of the bottle of Seizoen.  Theres a little bit of hay as well, and maybe I get a little bit of oats once it warms up, as well as very light floral notes.  Semi-dry finish with bitterness peaking at a 2, and had some lingering wheat.  I liked that the coriander was more a complementing ingredient, as opposed to a perfumey citrus bomb, as is the case so often. Moderate to high carbonation with a medium body.  A rustic witbier, probably more authentic than most Ive had, especially in the US. I need to stop by this place if Im ever in Oregon.  Shit, this tastes real.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle. pale amber beer with a whitish head. Yeast and spice aroma with light tartness. Spice and light yeast flavor with light wheat and light fruitiness. Medium bodied. Wheat and spice lingers with light yeast and light earthiness.
Hazy pale orange pour with big white head. Very Strong nose of corriander and citrus. Light body. Smells beautiful tastes pretty good. Good wit with broad appeal for summer

Bottle shared by Liz. Pours dishwater gold with a 4 finger foamy white head. Aroma of lots of coriander and yeast/spice. Med minus body. Flavor is lightly earthy, coriander/citrus. Finishes earthy/dry. Wit wanting to be farmhouse. Nice.

750mL bottle, split with manuchampions and uhlan, pours a murky orangey yellow with a small white head. Aroma of oranges, orange peel, coriander and wheat. Begins flavourful with orange peel, oranges and wheat upfront, but then whole thing dies to a very muted orange peel and wheat note. Turns to sparkling water at the end. Decent, but sort of dull.

Bottle...  Poured hazy pale, hazy, pale yellow-ish. Nose had lit fruits, passion fruit, wheat malts and spices.  Dry and crisp. Quite refreshing.  Vanilla sweetness, grains, earthy and grassy spices. Some floralness and a big fruit finish.
Pours a light orange.  Pretty foamy.  Aroma is minimal.  Very banana tasting.  Nice and carbonated.  Some orange notes but minimal.  A little spice in the middle.

Super cloudy orange brew with plenty of white lacing.  The beer is very earthy with some estery high-notes and green peppercorn hop character in the aroma.  Sweet and silky.  There is something like eggnog about this one, just a little something or maybe baby food.  The spicing is woody and interesting.  The yeast is banana-y and potent.  Pretty interesting but recognizable as a wit though it lacks that citrus.

Bottle thanks to a trade from BA. Poured hazy yellow with a white head that lasted the life of the beer. Aroma was citrus, yeast, coriander, and a touch of Orange. Flavor was Orange, coriander, yeast, and pilsner malt? Body was light, fuzzy, and dry. I am not much of a wit person, but this is tasty.

750 ml. bottle (as pictured), from The BeerMongers, in Portland. Fairly translucent, with a thin and wispy head. Not turbid enough, in my opinion. Lots of wheat hitting my nostrils. Its fairly pungent. Orange, cream, and a touch of coriander come through, too. A decent aroma. Wow, very carbonated its definitely got a carbonation bite to it, so its a little much, for me. Cream and orange poke through, so does the coriander. Bits of yeast flavor hit my taste buds. The flavor is quite nice, actually. The more I drink this, the more ambivalent I become, regarding the carbonation level. Solid taste, and a solid beer. Cheers.
